Introducing tgver

Source: vignettes/tgver.Rmd
tgver.Rmd

What is TGVE?

The Turing Geovisualisation Engine (TGVE or eAtlas) is a web-based, interactive visual analytics tool for geospatial data analysis, built using R & React. The visual views and interaction mechanisms designed into the tool is underpinned by empirically-informed guidelines around visualization design and techniques from Geographic Information Science (GIScience).

tgver R package

See the README on the package’s GitHub space.

Usage

As the package is not on CRAN yet, get it from GitHub using devtools

devtools::install_github("tgve/tgver")

The package comes with the latest version of TGVE and should give you the version used in the package:

tgver::version
#>        version 
#> "1.3.4-beta.4"

That means, there is no need to do anything to run a clean instance of the TGVE ready to import data to using:

tgver::tgve_server()

The application can be served from a plumber instance which is pointed at the location of the TGVE instance initialized, or directly opening the HTML file in browsers. This also means we can embed the application in an Rmd file, using either of the two methods, when building the Rmd (thanks to knitr):

# open a static tgve
# tgver::tgve()
# 
# or start a tgve instance before embedding it
# tgver::tgve_server()
# knitr::include_url("http://127.0.0.1:8000")
# or use the public one
knitr::include_url("https://tgve.github.io/eatlas-template/")

The above instance pulls the instance and the data from a GitHub repository, which means it should load every time the Rmd output is viewed (provided it is a html_vignette).

On your local machine, and given the Rmarkdown output is set to rmarkdown::html_vignette, then you could do:

# setup a local instance
# tempdir() will disappear inside an Rmd
p = "~/Downloads"
tgver::setup(p)
# now the instance is at
tp = file.path(p, "tgve")
# we just need to pass the data/csv URL
# using `defaultURL` API
url = tgver::build(tp, defaultURL = 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/layik/eatlas-data/main/utlas.geojson',
                   column = "long",
                   hideChartGenerator="true",
                   # In future R should assemble the json
                   viewport="{zoom:5.5,pitch:0,bearing:0}")
# now we have the app's main url
knitr::include_url(url)
# unlink(tp, recursive = TRUE)

If this Vignette is served either from CRAN or GitHub, the application at path in above chunk (tp) will not be available. So you must run it locally to see the application, the screenshot below was taken from such a run. Embedding the full instance in a HTML file is an open issue on the repository and we welcome your contributions if you can.

Also, please note that the “webview” within Rstudio Deb package version 1.4.1717 fails to load even remote URLs using knitr::include_url, please click the “open in browser” to see the rendering from knitr.

Main functions

The package still has “WIP” label on, so we are still finalizing the main functionality of the package. However, as of (November 2021) it looks like to work with the TGVE, we need:

  1. Setup function(s)
  2. Build function(s)
  3. Run function(s)

The package does have a function called setup which does what it says on the help; it sets up an instance at a given directory. The build function is there to pass parameters to the TGVE front-end, in other words it is a mini transpiler with bare minimum functionality (version 0.1.0).

For the third type of functions and to run the application, so far, there are few functions that can be used but the main one is tgve which sets up and builds a static and “empty” instance at a tempdir. The similar function called tgve_server does exactly the same but serves the instance from a local server using plumber APIs.

More important functions are:

  1. explore_fs: OGC standard Simple Features and R package sf is an important class object to support. Though we will do all we can to not import sf due to underlying system dependencies.
  2. explore_fil: this makes sense given the API and functionality built into the TGVE and given that data scientists would want to quickly explore single files.
  3. explore_dir: this is an ambitious function to develop. Current version tries to find two files and pass them to TGVE’s defaultURL and geographyURL as that is a use case of the TGVE.

This vignette is under active development.
